stream_context.summary: Kaze reviews recent off-stream progress on Course 15’s boss fight and spaceship interior, fixes VFX/engine regressions (smoke, transparency layers), and begins designing the level’s “retro section” (a Mario 64-themed traversal). The stream includes a major arena redesign idea (factory → planet), concrete memory/ROM-size checks, and discussion of workflow constraints, feedback saturation, and refusal to add extensive option toggles.
stream_context.significance_reason: Course 15 is described as the last main-course holdout; Kaze shows a newly built boss fight/off-stream work, says only one more sub-area remains before all main courses are finished, and pivots planning toward polishing/beta testing and the Mario 64-themed retro section.

findings.summary: Kaze says he has essentially finished Course 15’s boss fight and built most of the “inside of the rocket/spaceship” sub-area, with only one more sub-area left before all main courses are complete.
findings.quote: After that we have one more sub area to do in Course 15. And we’re finally done. Oh my God, dude, all the main courses will be finished.

findings.summary: Course 15’s boss fight features a mutated Yoshi with tentacle slams; the player destroys mushrooms on/around the boss, and the boss spawns “baby Yoshis” as adds (currently unanimated placeholders).
Zeina is actively animating the baby Yoshi enemies for the Course 15 boss fight; Kaze expects the fight to read better once those animations are in.
findings.quote: Zeina’s currently animating them. So hopefully they will be better once they are animated.

findings.summary: Kaze changed an earlier body-horror concept: tumors on the mutated Yoshi were replaced with mushrooms after feedback that tumors were too disgusting/traumatizing.
findings.quote: At first I had him grow tumors… they said this is way too disgusting. So I changed the tumors into mushrooms.

findings.summary: The boss fight tracks which mushrooms the player has already popped and uses that state to sometimes avoid respawning mushrooms, implying persistent per-fight/object state logic.
findings.quote: One cool thing I did is it remembers which mushrooms you’ve popped. And then it spawns no mushroom there sometimes.

findings.summary: Course 15’s spaceship interior is laid out as a sequence of themed rooms (computer room → specimen room with tanks → low-gravity transition → engine room with hot/no-touch zones → observatory with telescopes/holograms → glass dome star reveal). Kaze intends the player to feel briefly lost, then discover traversal cues (stairs, suction dust, etc.).
Kaze intentionally teases an early, visible but initially unreachable star to keep the player motivated throughout the level, describing it as “edging” the player.
findings.quote: It’s very important to constantly edge the player… we’re going to edge the player with the star right away so they have that in mind forever.

findings.summary: A viewer/“Biobak” brainstorm prompts Kaze to replace a planned ‘factory’ boss arena with a simpler, cooler concept: fighting on/around a planet that the boss breaks apart (e.g., drilling/spinning/Beyblade-like destruction), leaving the boss head/core central as a hazard.
findings.quote: That would also be lower poly than my whole stupid factory here… Planet is cooler.

findings.summary: Kaze verifies current ROM size is ~58.8 MB, stating it still fits within a 64 MB cartridge budget, and later notes there is a little over ~0.5 MB of free RAM headroom in the current scene.
findings.quote: We can check how big the ROM is right now. 58.8 megabytes. We’re still pretty good in size.

findings.summary: Engine evolution is causing regressions in older content; Kaze notes that changing microcode/engine systems breaks existing levels (e.g., portal animation broke; old levels generate invalid display lists; transparency layering behavior changed).
findings.quote: This is what happens when you keep changing the engine— all the levels just break.

findings.summary: Kaze debugged missing “burn smoke” VFX: it stopped working because he changed a struct; after fixing, he adds an optimization so smoke only spawns when the effect is in view (camera-facing/visibility gated), enabling heavier VFX without tanking performance.
findings.quote: This lets us add so much more smoke… we can add so much fucking smoke now.

findings.summary: There is a rare crash triggered by performing a BLJ (backwards long jump). Kaze demonstrates the crash, denies he intentionally disabled BLJs, and says he needs to investigate the underlying bug (possibly an infinite loop/action-state issue).
findings.quote: I still have a rare bug in my game… BLJ crashes… Obviously do not want that.

findings.summary: Kaze says demo feedback has largely saturated: newer feedback is often contradictory or overly nitpicky, reducing its usefulness for changing decisions, though he still listens for genuinely new insights.
findings.quote: At this point I think I have all the demo feedback I could ever need… a lot of the feedback I’m getting now is either super nitpicky or contradicting another feedback.

findings.summary: Kaze strongly resists adding extensive player options (especially toggles to revert movement/physics), arguing it would bloat development and create an unusable menu. He frames code quality as simplification/line removal rather than feature accretion.
findings.quote: If I added everyone’s request for options, I would have an option menu with 260 items.

findings.summary: Kaze mentions securing guest authors for some levels (Hazer and Martiste). He shows a pastel, Yoshi’s Island-inspired side level concept with wind-sliding and flowers, describing it as pretty but still needing “sauce,” and expresses uncertainty about whether the current direction will be fun.
findings.quote: It looks like I managed to get some guest authors for a few of the levels… Hazer and Martiste.

biobak.summary: Biobak contributes/endorses the major arena redesign idea: shifting the final Course 15 boss arena from a factory concept to a planet that gets broken apart, emphasizing the “banger” potential and simplicity.
biobak.quote: That’s true, Biobak, it’s a banger idea.

biobak.summary: Biobak provides art/tech critique on environment readability (UV mapping problems making cogs/pipes hard to see) and generally gives real-time visual feedback as Kaze tours the spaceship interior.

badub.summary: Kaze references upcoming/expected music from Badub for the Mario 64-themed retro section, indicating dependency on new composition for that segment.
badub.quote: Oh yeah, Badub’s [music] on the retro section? Dude, I’m looking forward to that.

zeina.summary: Zeina is animating the baby Yoshi enemies for the mutated Yoshi boss encounter; Kaze also references Zeina’s involvement in polishing demo/feedback items and her presence working nearby during the stream.

findings.summary: Hazer is working as a guest author on a pastel, Yoshi’s Island-like side level featuring wind/sliding movement and heavy flower theming; Kaze likes the look but thinks it needs additional “sauce” to be fully compelling.
Martiste is mentioned as another guest author contributing to a level (details not shown in this stream).
Kaze showcases a pastel, Yoshi’s Island-inspired level attributed to Aezawaza (possibly the same as or distinct from Hazer’s work), noting its simplicity and strong thematic fit.
findings.quote: Very pastel color, very Yoshi’s Island, and that’s why I like it.

findings.summary: A community member (“HooliKaleb”) offers to convert/handle old SM64 level-rip files; Kaze shares a .rar of SM64 levels and asks not to modify them, reflecting reliance on community help for pipeline friction.
findings.quote: I only need the 15 main courses and the castle grounds… Do not change the levels, please.

findings.summary: Kaze live-reacts to GreenSuichi’s Last Impact zero-star world record, using it as a reflective design postmortem on his older hack (constraints, coherence, and speedrun-friendly skips he left intentionally).

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I’ve come to realize that it’s very important to constantly edge the player.
memorable_quotes.context: Explaining why he places an early, visible star in the glass dome so players keep it as a long-term goal while exploring the spaceship.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: This is what happens when you keep changing the engine— all the levels just break.
memorable_quotes.context: Reacting to broken portal/legacy-level behavior after ongoing engine/microcode changes; captures the cost of ambitious tech iteration on a long project.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: If I added everyone’s request for options, I would have an option menu with 260 items.
memorable_quotes.context: Arguing against adding extensive optional toggles (especially reverting physics), framing it as harmful bloat and wasted dev time.

key_stories.title: Course 15 boss fight iteration: tentacles, mushrooms, and baby Yoshis
key_stories.summary: Kaze shows a largely finished boss fight built partly off-stream: a mutated Yoshi attacks with tentacle slams while Mario pops mushrooms and manages spawned baby Yoshis. Visual tone was revised after feedback that the original ‘tumor’ concept was too gross, and the baby Yoshi enemies are awaiting Zeina’s animations.
key_stories.challenge: Make a readable, fun, and thematically appropriate final-course boss without overwhelming players or crossing into off-putting body horror.
key_stories.process: Prototype tentacle attack patterns and add mechanics; replace tumors with mushrooms; implement state so popped mushrooms may not respawn; identify issues like excessive baby-Yoshi spawns and overlapping tentacles; plan animation upgrades via Zeina.
key_stories.outcome: Fight is functional but needs tuning (spawn counts/difficulty, overlapping attacks) and animation polish; mushrooms-as-weakpoints becomes the chosen aesthetic/mechanic direction.
key_stories.key_quote: At first I had him grow tumors… So I changed the tumors into mushrooms.

key_stories.title: Boss arena pivot: factory concept replaced by a destroyed-planet arena
key_stories.summary: During brainstorming, Kaze warms to replacing his planned factory arena with a cleaner, cooler planet arena where the boss breaks the planet apart (drill/spin/Beyblade-style), leaving a central hazard (core/head). He prefers this because it is more exciting visually and simpler/cheaper to build than the factory.
key_stories.challenge: Find an arena concept that is visually striking, readable, and feasible on N64 constraints while reducing complexity and art burden.
key_stories.process: Discuss multiple destruction beats (clean break, drilling through planet, debris, portals); evaluate readability and implementation cost; explicitly rejects the factory as uninteresting and too much work.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze writes down the plan to stage the Yoshi fight on the “8th planet,” with a central head/core hazard and VFX-driven destruction rather than a full factory build.
key_stories.key_quote: That would also be lower poly than my whole stupid factory here… Planet is cooler.

key_stories.title: VFX regression and performance unlock: fixing burn smoke and gating spawns by camera view
key_stories.summary: Kaze investigates why a burn-smoke effect no longer appears, traces it to a changed struct, and restores the effect. He then adds logic to prevent smoke from spawning when it’s out of view, enabling denser VFX without tanking performance.
key_stories.challenge: A previously working VFX system stopped rendering due to engine refactors, and naïvely spawning lots of smoke could be too expensive.
key_stories.process: Verify the effect is missing in multiple courses; compare against other smoke usages; identify struct mismatch; fix spawner; implement visibility-based spawn gating and test by whipping the camera to confirm no off-screen accumulation.
key_stories.outcome: Smoke returns and becomes scalable; Kaze notes a strange ‘spawns once then stops’ behavior in the new gating setup and decides to keep the functionality but leave it unused until understood.
key_stories.key_quote: This lets us add so much more smoke…

key_stories.title: Mario 64 retro section planning and pipeline friction with old SM64 level rips
key_stories.summary: Kaze plans Course 15’s retro section to evoke classic Mario 64 by traversing small highlights of several SM64 courses as floating snippets in space. He tries to retrieve old SM64 level rips but discovers they are .skp (SketchUp) files from 2018, leading to conversion hassles and reliance on community help.
key_stories.challenge: Create a cohesive SM64 ‘best-of’ traversal without it becoming too big, while dealing with outdated asset formats/pipeline issues.
key_stories.process: Iterate from ‘full course tour’ to ‘highlights only’ to ‘floating snippet islands’; enumerate candidate areas (BoB bridge, WF tower start, JRB ship/boat/pillars, CCM cabin/snowman bridge, Big Boo’s Haunt, Lethal Lava Land volcano, TTM slide, etc.); attempt online conversion; contact a community member to handle file conversion/sharing.
key_stories.outcome: Direction settles on modular snippet-to-snippet platforming; conversion work is offloaded; Kaze notes memory headroom and believes import is feasible.
key_stories.key_quote: We’re gonna take like just a very small piece of each course.

key_stories.title: The BLJ crash: acknowledging unintended tech and the cost of uncertainty
key_stories.summary: Kaze demonstrates that BLJs are possible in RTYI but sometimes crash the game, causing total shutdown. He rejects the idea that he intentionally removed BLJs and frames the crash as an unknown bug requiring investigation.
key_stories.challenge: A rare but severe crash tied to a high-profile movement technique undermines stability and invites speculation about intentional design changes.
key_stories.process: Reproduce on stream; speculate about underlying causes (infinite loop, null pointer, action state toggling); commits to investigating rather than guessing.
key_stories.outcome: Crash remains unresolved in this stream but becomes a concrete stability task to fix during upcoming beta-testing/polish passes after Course 15.
key_stories.key_quote: It’s a bug and that means it’s an issue that I don’t know the reason for.

open_questions.topic: Course 15 finalization plan and remaining sub-area
open_questions.context: Kaze says only one more sub-area in Course 15 remains before all main courses are finished, but does not detail what that sub-area is or what gates completion.
questions: What exactly is the remaining Course 15 sub-area and its star/objective structure?
What criteria define ‘Course 15 is done’ (all stars implemented, performance targets, art polish)?
What’s the internal checklist before moving from ‘main courses finished’ to ‘polish/beta testing’?

open_questions.topic: Mutated Yoshi boss fight tuning and readability
open_questions.context: The boss spawns too many baby Yoshis, tentacle attacks can overlap, and some mechanics may be too slow/unclear (hot platforms visibility, fall hazards).
questions: What is the intended difficulty curve for the boss, and what player skills should it test?
How many baby Yoshis is ‘fun’ versus ‘overwhelming,’ and how will their AI/animations communicate threats?
How will you prevent tentacle overlaps or unfair hits while keeping the fight dynamic?
How do you decide when jank is acceptable ‘Mario 64 jank’ versus a fix-worthy bug?

open_questions.topic: Arena redesign: planet-destruction cutscene and implementation details
open_questions.context: Kaze prefers a planet arena over a factory, discussing drilling/spinning destruction, debris, portals, and central hazard layout, but no final implementation is chosen.
questions: What is the final storyboard for the planet destruction moment (camera language, timing, player control)?
How will you implement the planet breaking on N64 (mesh swaps, segment hiding, debris particles, collision changes)?
Will the boss arena design affect story/lore (why this planet, why the mutation)?

open_questions.topic: Retro section scope: selecting highlights and making traversal coherent
open_questions.context: Kaze iterates through multiple structures for the SM64 retro section and lists candidate snippets but hasn’t finalized the route or transitions.
questions: What is the final ‘route’ through SM64 highlights, and what’s the thematic reason for each selection?
How will transitions between snippets be communicated (portals, visual bridges, narrative justification)?
Will gameplay be pure platforming, or include classic SM64 hazards/enemies tuned to RTYI movement?
How will you avoid the retro section feeling like ‘shitting on vanilla SM64’ versus celebrating it?

open_questions.topic: Guest authorship: Hazer/Martiste scope and integration standards
open_questions.context: Kaze mentions guest authors and shows a pastel wind-sliding flower level, but it’s unclear how much autonomy guests have and what review process exists.
questions: What guidelines do guest authors receive (movement tech expectations, difficulty, star design, performance budgets)?
How do you ensure consistent art direction and mechanical language across guest-made levels?
What did Hazer and Martiste each deliver (greybox, full level, scripting, art), and what remains for Kaze to integrate?

open_questions.topic: Engine/microcode evolution and content breakage strategy
open_questions.context: Kaze notes engine changes frequently break older levels (transparency layer semantics, display lists, portal animation).
questions: What’s the plan to stabilize the engine before the full-game polish pass?
How do you track regressions across many courses (automated tests, checklists, ‘beta sweep’ schedule)?
What were the biggest engine changes recently (microcode, render layers), and why were they worth the breakage risk?

open_questions.topic: VFX visibility gating bug (‘spawns once then stops’)
open_questions.context: After adding in-view spawning, smoke sometimes spawns once and then stops; Kaze finds it bizarre and leaves the feature unused for now.
questions: What caused the ‘once then never again’ behavior (state flag, RNG seed, object lifecycle, camera tests)?
Do you have a general VFX architecture (emitters, lifetime, pooling), and how will you prevent similar regressions?
How do you decide when to keep a half-working optimization versus reverting for stability?

open_questions.topic: Stability: BLJ crash root cause and decision on preserving BLJ tech
open_questions.context: BLJ sometimes crashes the game; Kaze denies intentionally removing BLJ and wants to fix the crash.
questions: What’s your stance on preserving BLJ and other speedrun tech in RTYI—feature, acceptable exploit, or something to patch?
What debugging path will you use to isolate the BLJ crash (action-state tracing, memory watchpoints, repro conditions)?
Are there other known crashers or only BLJ-related ones?

open_questions.topic: Final boss concept and story integration
open_questions.context: Kaze hasn’t decided the final boss; he floats the idea that Yoshis build something for Bowser, but nothing is locked in.
questions: What is the current story outline leading into the final boss, and what themes must the boss pay off?
What candidates are on the table (mech, creation of Yoshis, something they built), and why?
How early did you decide to prioritize story inspiration for the final boss, and what references are you drawing from?

open_questions.topic: Performance budgets: ROM size, RAM headroom, and N64 constraints
open_questions.context: Kaze cites ROM size (58.8MB) and ~0.5MB RAM headroom, and repeatedly frames design decisions through poly/VFX cost.
questions: What are your hard budgets per level for geometry, textures, and VFX?
Where have you hit the tightest memory constraints so far, and what compromises did you make?
Do you foresee needing a second build target (emulator vs real hardware) for heavier scenes, or will everything stay hardware-accurate?
What tools do you use to measure and attribute RAM usage across assets/objects?
